TENNIS MATCH
Fresh from 5-2 Victory Over Delaware, Netmen Expect New
Faces in Lineup
Having defeated Delaware last
Saturday five matches to one, the
Johns Hopkins tennis team is
looking forward to a win in tomorrow's encounter with Loyola
• . _—
College on the Homewood courts.
The first match is scheduled to
begin at 2 o'clock. This meeting
with Loyola tomorrow is the result of a postponement because of
rain several weeks .ago.
Little is known of Loyola's
strength ; however, several members of tilt Catholic- institution's
tennis• team have been getting accustomed to the Homewood tennis courts during the past Week,
and they seem determined to win
tomorroW.
Last Saturday Captain jean
Hofmeister's racquetters won
their match with the University
of Delaware. Hofmeister disposed of Delaware's number one
man rather easily, defeating him
6-1, 6-4. Little Charley Wasserman, a freshman, provided the
thrills of the afternoon in his
match with Challenger. Wasserman dropped the first set 4-0, but
pulled through the second by a
12-10 score and then won the
match by breezing through to a
6-2 victory in the final set. Kaufholz, also a first-year man, won ill

match by breezing through to a
